hotspots.label: Metal Railroad Tracks
hotspots.fact: Railroad tracks are made of metal, which is a material that can conduct heat and electricity very well. The metal rails are designed to support the heavy weight of trains through their strong structure, and trains can move smoothly along the tracks because of the flat surface and low friction between the metal wheels and metal rails.

vocabulary.definition: A force that slows things down when two surfaces rub together; metal on metal has low friction, so trains slide easily.

hotspots.label: Tree Canopy Overhead
hotspots.fact: The trees form a natural tunnel over the tracks, and their green leaves are absorbing sunlight to make energy for the plant. This dense forest also shows how matter and energy flow through natureâ€”the trees use light energy from the sun to grow, and they provide shade and shelter to the area below.

vocabulary.definition: The power to make things move or change; plants get energy from sunlight to grow and stay alive.

hotspots.label: Gravel and Ballast Bed
hotspots.fact: The rocks beneath the railroad tracks are called ballast, and they are an important part of the track's design. The gravel provides drainage so water doesn't pool under the tracks, and it also holds the wooden ties in place, keeping the tracks at the correct distance apart so trains can run safely and smoothly.

vocabulary.definition: Small rocks or gravel placed under railroad tracks to keep them stable and properly spaced.

hotspots.label: Wooden Railroad Ties
hotspots.fact: The dark wooden pieces connecting the two metal rails are called ties or sleepers, and they transfer the heavy weight of passing trains down to the gravel below. Wood is chosen for this job because it has the physical property of being strong and rigid, which means it resists bending even under heavy loads.

vocabulary.definition: Stiff and hard to bend; rigid materials like wood keep their shape even when pushed or pressed.
